<FONT FACE="WINGDINGS">&#253;</FONT> Form&nbsp;40-F&nbsp;<FONT FACE="WINGDINGS">&#111;</FONT> </FONT></P>

submitted solely to provide an attached annual report to security holders. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Indicate
by check mark if the registrant is submitting the Form&nbsp;6-K in paper as permitted by Regulation&nbsp;S-T
Rule&nbsp;101&nbsp;(b)(7):&nbsp;<U>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</U> </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note:</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regulation&nbsp;S-T Rule&nbsp;101(b)(7) only permits the submission in paper of a Form&nbsp;6-K if
submitted to furnish a report or other document that the registrant foreign private issuer must furnish and make public under the laws of the jurisdiction in which the registrant is incorporated,
domiciled or legally organized (the&nbsp;registrant's "home country"), or under the rules of the home country exchange on which the registrant's securities are traded, as long as the report or other
document is not a press release, is not required to be and has not been distributed to the registrant's security holders, and, if discussing a material event, has already been the subject of a
Form&nbsp;6-K submission or other Commission filing on&nbsp;EDGAR. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;text-align:justify"><FONT SIZE=2>Indicate
by check mark whether the registrant by furnishing the information contained in this Form is also thereby furnishing the information to the Commission pursuant to
Rule&nbsp;12g3-2(b) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Yes <FONT FACE="WINGDINGS">&#111;</FONT> No&nbsp;<FONT FACE="WINGDINGS">&#253;</FONT> </FONT></P>

<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>  Exhibit&nbsp;99.1    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><BR><BR><BR><BR> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>
<IMG SRC="g34403.jpg" ALT="LOGO" WIDTH="238" HEIGHT="238">
  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><BR><BR> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=5><B>First Quarter Report 2010  </B></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=1,EFW="2198467",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="2",CHK=57423,FOLIO='blank',FILE='DISK125:[10ZAZ1.10ZAZ12201]BE12201A.;2',USER='RMCIVOR',CD='30-APR-2010;09:09' -->

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="da12201_quarterly_management_s_discuss__qua08225"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_da12201_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>  QUARTERLY MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<BR>  <BR>    UNITED STATES GAAP<BR>  <BR>    (all&nbsp;figures are expressed in US dollars unless otherwise noted and<BR>  all units of measurement expressed in metric unless
otherwise noted)    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Results of Operations  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Agnico-Eagle Mines Limited ("Agnico-Eagle" or the "Company") reported first quarter net income of $22.3&nbsp;million, or $0.14 per
share, compared to net income of $54.3&nbsp;million, or $0.35 per share, in the first quarter of 2009. In the first quarter of 2010, the operating margin more than doubled to $119.4&nbsp;million
from $56.1&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2009 due to an overall strong operating performance and the substantial increase in production by the Company's new mines. Gold production in the
first quarter of 2010 more than doubled to 188,232&nbsp;ounces from 91,812&nbsp;ounces in the first quarter of 2009 due to the commencement of production at the Kittila, Lapa, Pinos Altos and
Meadowbank mines. The substantial increase in operating margin was partially offset by an increase in non cash income taxes, non cash foreign exchange loss and non cash corporate costs. Cash provided
by operating activities was $74.5&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2010 compared to cash provided from operating activities of $48.8&nbsp;million in the prior year's first quarter. The impact
of significantly higher gold production, compared to the first quarter of 2009, was partially offset by changes in working capital related to a build-up of stockpile and concentrate
inventory at the Company's new&nbsp;mines. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
table below summarizes the key variances in net income for the first quarter of 2010 from the net income reported for the same period in&nbsp;2009: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size:1.5pt;" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><p style="font-family:times;margin-left:10pt;text-indent:-10pt;"><FONT SIZE=2> </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Net variance</B></FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>(32.0</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size:1.5pt;" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
March&nbsp;1, 2010, the Meadowbank mine achieved commercial production. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2010, revenues from mining operations increased to $237.6&nbsp;million from $105.8&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2009. This was mainly due to the
increase in gold production by the Kittila, Lapa, Pinos Altos and Meadowbank mines that were not in commercial production in the first quarter of 2009. These four mines produced an incremental
96,413&nbsp;ounces during the first quarter of 2010 when compared to the first quarter of 2009. In addition, during the first quarter of 2010, there were higher realized prices for all metals when
compared to the first quarter of&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2010, total cash costs per ounce increased to $443 per ounce of gold produced from $312 per ounce in the first quarter of 2009. This increase in total cash costs
is attributable to the fact that the Kittila, Lapa and Meadowbank mines are producing only gold with no credits against production costs from byproduct revenue and that the Kittila and Meadowbank
mines are currently not operating at full&nbsp;capacity. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the first quarter of 2010, production costs increased to $118.2&nbsp;million from $49.7&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2009 due to the production at the Kittila, Lapa,
Pinos Altos and Meadowbank mines. Production costs also increased due to the strengthening of the Canadian dollar and Euro. Also during the first quarter of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>1</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=2,EFW="2198467",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="2",CHK=545883,FOLIO='1',FILE='DISK125:[10ZAZ1.10ZAZ12201]DA12201A.;20',USER='FALVARE',CD='12-MAY-2010;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_da12201_1_2"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>2010,
depreciation and amortization expense increased to $30.5&nbsp;million from $12.1&nbsp;million also due to the increased production at the Company's new&nbsp;mines. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2010, general and administrative expense increased to $28.4&nbsp;million from $18.8&nbsp;million mainly due to an increase in stock option expense driven by
the Company's stock option grant in January 2010. Also during the first quarter, there was a non-cash foreign currency translation loss of $8.9&nbsp;million compared to a gain of
$7.5&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2009 due to the strengthening of both the Canadian dollar and the Euro against the US dollar. In the first quarter, income and mining taxes increased to
$18.9&nbsp;million from a tax recovery of $25.0&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2009 mainly due to the Company's election to commence using the US dollar as its functional currency for
federal Canadian income tax purposes in&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following tables provides a reconciliation of the total cash costs per ounce of gold produced and mine site costs per tonne to the interim consolidated financial statements for the
LaRonde, Goldex, Lapa, Kittila, Pinos Altos and Meadowbank mines: </FONT></P>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Notes: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(i)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Under
the Company's revenue recognition policy, revenue is recognized on concentrates when legal title passes. Since total cash costs are calculated on a
production basis, this inventory adjustment reflects the sales margin on the portion of concentrate production for which revenue has not been recognized in the&nbsp;period.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(ii)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Total
cash costs is not a recognized measure under US GAAP and this data may not be comparable to data presented by other gold producers. The Company
believes that this generally accepted industry measure is a realistic indication of operating performance and is useful in allowing year over year comparisons. As illustrated in the table above, this
measure is calculated by adjusting Production Costs as shown in the Consolidated Statements of Income and Comprehensive Income for net byproduct revenues, inventory adjustments and asset retirement
provisions. This measure is intended to provide investors with information about the cash generating capabilities of the Company's mining operations. Management uses this measure to monitor the
performance of the Company's mining operations. Since market prices for gold are quoted on a per ounce basis, using this per ounce measure allows management to assess the mine's cash generating
capabilities at various gold prices. Management is aware that this per ounce measure of performance can be impacted by fluctuations in byproduct metal prices and exchange rates. Management compensates
for the limitation inherent with this measure by using it in conjunction with the minesite costs per tonne measure (discussed below) as well as other data prepared in accordance with US GAAP.
Management also performs sensitivity analyses in order to quantify the effects of fluctuating metal prices and exchange&nbsp;rates.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(iii)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>This
inventory adjustment reflects production costs associated with unsold concentrates.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(iv)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Minesite
costs per tonne is not a recognized measure under US GAAP and this data may not be comparable to data presented by other gold producers. As
illustrated in the table above, this measure is calculated by adjusting Production Costs as shown in the Consolidated Statements of Income and Comprehensive Income for inventory and hedging
adjustments (if&nbsp;any) and asset retirement provisions and then dividing by tonnes processed through the mill. Since total cash costs data can be affected by fluctuations in byproduct metal
prices and exchange rates, management believes minesite costs per tonne provides additional information regarding the performance of mining operations and allows management to monitor operating costs
on a more consistent basis as the per tonne measure eliminates the cost variability associated with varying production levels. Management also uses this measure to determine the economic viability of
mining blocks. As each mining block is evaluated based on the net realizable value of each tonne mined, in order to be economically viable the estimated revenue on a per tonne basis must be in excess
of the minesite costs per tonne. Management is aware that this per tonne measure is impacted by fluctuations in production levels and thus uses this evaluation tool in conjunction with production
costs prepared in accordance with US GAAP. This measure supplements production cost information prepared in accordance with US GAAP and allows investors to distinguish between changes in production
costs resulting from changes in production versus changes in operating performance. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>5</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=6,EFW="2198467",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="2",CHK=483047,FOLIO='5',FILE='DISK125:[10ZAZ1.10ZAZ12201]DA12201A.;20',USER='FALVARE',CD='12-MAY-2010;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_da12201_1_6"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Liquidity and Capital Resources  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At March&nbsp;31, 2010, Agnico-Eagle's cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments and restricted cash totalled
$118.1&nbsp;million, while working capital was $442.2&nbsp;million. At December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had $163.6&nbsp;million in cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments
and restricted cash and $413.6&nbsp;million in working capital. The Company's policy is to invest excess cash in highly liquid investments of the highest credit quality to eliminate any risks
associated with these investments. Such investments with remaining maturities at time of purchase greater than three months are classified as short-term investments and decisions regarding
the length of maturities are based on cash flow requirements, rates of returns and various other&nbsp;factors. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
provided by operating activities was $74.5&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2010 compared to cash provided by operating activities of $48.8&nbsp;million in the first quarter
of 2009. In the first quarter of 2010, revenues from mining operations increased to $237.6&nbsp;million from $105.8&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2009. This was mainly due to the increase
in gold production by the Kittila, Lapa, Pinos Altos and Meadowbank mines that were not in commercial production in the first quarter of 2009 and the higher realized sales prices for all metals. The
impact of significantly higher gold production and realized sales price for all metals compared to the first quarter of 2009, was partially offset by changes in working capital related to a
build-up of stockpile and concentrate inventory at the Company's new mines and the decrease in trade&nbsp;payables. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010, capital expenditures were $112.6&nbsp;million compared to $155.3&nbsp;million in the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2009. The
significant capital expenditures during the first quarter of 2010 pertained to the Meadowbank mine, the LaRonde depth extension project and the Creston Mascota project. The capital expenditures were
significantly lower during the first quarter of 2010 when
compared to the first quarter of 2009 due to the completion of construction activities at the Kittila, Lapa and Pinos Altos&nbsp;mines. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the second quarter of 2009, Agnico-Eagle executed a new non-amortizing $600&nbsp;million revolving credit facility, maturing in June&nbsp;2012. The new facility
replaces a pre-existing $300&nbsp;million tranche of the Company's credit lines that would have matured in September&nbsp;2010. The new facility together with the remaining tranche of
the pre-existing credit facilities (non-amortizing $300&nbsp;million revolving credit line, maturing January&nbsp;2013), allow for borrowings of up to $900&nbsp;million.
Both credit facilities are unsecured. During the second quarter of 2009, Agnico-Eagle also executed an unsecured C$95&nbsp;million bonding facility with Export Development Canada. This facility
matures in June&nbsp;2014 and will be used to provide letters of credit for environmental obligations or in relation to license or permit bonds relating to the Meadowbank Mine. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the first quarter of 2009, the Company drew down an additional $20&nbsp;million from its bank debt facilities. As of March&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company had $165&nbsp;million
in undrawn credit lines. The amount available under the facility is reduced by letters of credit drawn under the facility. Letters of Credit outstanding under the facility at March&nbsp;31, 2010
amounted to $23.3&nbsp;million, and therefore, the amount available to be borrowed as of March&nbsp;31, 2010, was approximately $142&nbsp;million. The facility requires the Company to maintain
specified financial ratios and meet financial condition covenants. These financial condition covenants were met at March&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent
to the end of the first quarter, the Company closed a private placement of notes consisting of $600&nbsp;million of guaranteed senior unsecured notes due in 2017, 2020 and
2022 with a weighted average maturity of 9.84&nbsp;years and weighted average yield of 6.59%. The net proceeds from the sale of the notes have been used to reduce amounts outstanding under the
Company's credit lines after quarter&nbsp;end. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also
subsequent to the first quarter of 2010, the Company and Comaplex Minerals Corp. ("Comaplex") jointly announced that they have entered into a definitive agreement whereby the
Company will acquire all of the shares of Comaplex that it does not already own. Under the terms of the transaction, each shareholder of Comaplex other than Agnico-Eagle, will receive 0.1576 of an
Agnico-Eagle share per Comaplex share. Additionally, at closing, each Comaplex shareholder other than Agnico-Eagle and Perfora Investments S.a.r.l. ("Perfora") will receive one common share of a newly
formed, wholly owned, subsidiary of Comaplex ("New&nbsp;Comaplex") in respect of each Comaplex share. The boards of directors of both companies have unanimously approved the acquisition agreement. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>6</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=7,EFW="2198467",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="2",CHK=478879,FOLIO='6',FILE='DISK125:[10ZAZ1.10ZAZ12201]DA12201A.;20',USER='FALVARE',CD='12-MAY-2010;09:02' -->
<A NAME="page_da12201_1_7"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
transaction contemplates that Comaplex will transfer to New&nbsp;Comaplex all assets and related liabilities other than those relating to the Meliadine properties and related
assets. These assets include all of Comaplex's net cash, the non-Meliadine mineral properties, all oil and gas properties, and investments. The shares of New&nbsp;Comaplex will be
distributed to the shareholders of Comaplex, other than Agnico-Eagle and&nbsp;Perfora. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Comaplex's
100% owned interest in the advanced stage Meliadine gold project located in Nunavut, Canada is approximately 300&nbsp;kilometres from Agnico-Eagle's producing Meadowbank
Mine. The Company believes the acquisition of Comaplex is consistent with its corporate strategy to "acquire small, think big." The Meliadine gold project is an early stage opportunity in a region
that the Company believes is of low political risk and well matched to Agnico-Eagle's skills and abilities. The Company believes it will be able to leverage off its operations base in Quebec, Canada
and create synergies with its current Arctic gold mining activities at the Meadowbank&nbsp;Mine. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
transaction is subject to approval by Comaplex shareholders and court and regulatory approvals, with an expected closing date in July&nbsp;2010. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the first quarter of 2010, the Company paid its annual 2009 annual dividend amounting to $26.8&nbsp;million. Also during the first quarter of 2010, $5.2&nbsp;million of common
shares were issued which was attributable to the employee share purchase plan and the exercising of stock&nbsp;options. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volatility
remains high in global financial markets and weakness in the global economy continues to have a serious impact on the profitability and liquidity of many businesses. Although
there are signs of stabilization, the timing of a return to historical market conditions is uncertain. Virtually all industries, including the gold mining business, have been affected by weak economic
conditions and volatile financial markets. Positive signs for the global economy include a relative easing of credit risk spreads, a reduction in financial systemic risk, lower levels of volatility in
many markets and an improvement in investor confidence. However, economic data show mixed signals for the likelihood of sustained near-term economic recovery, and the costs of funding for
many businesses, especially for financial institutions with which we do business, remain high compared to historical levels. A prolonged global recession and continuation of volatility in world
markets could have a significant impact on our business. In particular, the global credit/liquidity crisis could continue to affect the cost and availability of financing and our overall liquidity.
The volatility in gold, silver, zinc and copper prices affects the amount of our revenues, and our earnings and cash flow. Volatile energy prices, commodity and consumables prices and currency
exchange rates impact our production costs. The volatility of global stock markets impacts the valuation of our equity investments. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>7</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Notes:
</FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Payable mineral production means the quantity of mineral produced during a period contained in products that are or will be sold by the
Company, whether such products are sold during the period or held as inventory at the end of the&nbsp;period.  </FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Total
cash costs per ounce is a non-US GAAP measure of performance that the Company uses to monitor the performance of its operations. See
"Results of Operations&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Production Costs". </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>9</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="toc_fk12201_1"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>  AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED    <BR>    <BR>    NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS    <BR>    <BR>    (thousands of United States dollars except share and per share amounts, unless
otherwise indicated)<BR>  (Unaudited)<BR>  March 31, 2010    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BASIS OF PRESENTATION  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
accompanying unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of Agnico-Eagle Mines Limited ("Agnico-Eagle" or the&nbsp;"Company") have been prepared in accordance with United&nbsp;States
generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP") in US dollars. They do not include all of the disclosures required by GAAP for annual financial statements. Accordingly, these unaudited interim
consolidated financial statements should be read in conjunction with the fiscal 2009 annual consolidated financial statements, including the accounting policies and notes thereto, included in the
Annual Report and Annual Information Form/Form&nbsp;20-F for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009. In the opinion of management, the unaudited interim consolidated financial
statements reflect all adjustments, which consist only of normal and recurring adjustments necessary to present fairly the financial position as at March&nbsp;31, 2010 and the results of operations
and cash flows for the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010 and&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Operating
results for the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010 are not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for the full year ending December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2010. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;USE OF ESTIMATES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
preparation of the financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements and
accompanying notes. Management believes that the estimates used in the preparation of the interim consolidated financial statements are reasonable and prudent; however, actual results could differ
from these estimates. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ACCOUNTING POLICIES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>These
interim consolidated financial statements follow the same accounting policies and methods of their application as the December&nbsp;31, 2009 audited annual consolidated financial statements
except for the changes discussed below. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> <U>Recently Adopted Accounting Pronouncements</U>  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><I> Variable Interest Entities  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
June&nbsp;2009, the FASB issued an amendment to its guidance for consolidation accounting to require an entity to perform a qualitative analysis to determine whether the enterprise's variable
interest gives it a controlling financial interest in a VIE. The updated guidance also requires ongoing reassessments of the primary beneficiary of a VIE. Based on the Company's assessment, these
changes do not have an impact on the accounting for our existing&nbsp;VIE. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><I> Fair Value Accounting  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
January&nbsp;2010, the FASB guidance for fair value measurements and disclosures was updated to require additional disclosures. The updated guidance was effective for the Company's fiscal year
beginning January&nbsp;1, 2010, with the exception of the level&nbsp;3 disaggregation which is effective for the Company's fiscal year beginning January&nbsp;2, 2011. Based on the Company's
assessment, these changes do not have an impact on the Company's required disclosures. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENT  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Accounting
Standards Codification ("ASC") 820&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure (Prior authoritative literature: FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157, "Fair Value
Measurements") defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value under GAAP, and requires expanded disclosures about fair value measurements. The three levels of the fair value
hierarchy under the Fair Value Measurements and Disclosure Topic of the FASB Accounting Standards Codification&nbsp;are: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Level&nbsp;1&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Unadjusted
quoted prices in active markets that are accessible at the measurement date for identical, unrestricted assets or&nbsp;liabilities; </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Level&nbsp;2&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Quoted
prices in markets that are not active, or inputs that are observable, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of
the asset or&nbsp;liability; </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Level&nbsp;3&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Prices
or&nbsp;valuation techniques that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and unobservable (supported by
little or no market activity). </FONT></P>

</UL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>15</FONT></P>

<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

March 31, 2010 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENT (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Fair
value is the value at which a financial instrument could be closed out or sold in a transaction with a willing and knowledgeable counterparty over a period of time consistent with the Company's
investment strategy. Fair value is based on quoted market prices, where available. If market quotes are not available, fair value is based on internally developed models that use market-based or
independent information as inputs. These models could produce a fair value that may not be reflective of future fair&nbsp;value. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
following table sets forth the Company's financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value within the fair value hierarchy. </FONT></P>
</UL>

<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>860,975</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT"  style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>$</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&#151;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size:1.5pt;" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Fair
value approximates the carrying amounts due to the short-term nature.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Recorded
at fair value using quoted market prices.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Recorded
at fair value based on broker-dealer quotations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(4)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Assets
for the defined benefit pension plan consists of deposits on hand with regulatory authorities which are refundable when benefit payments are made
on the ultimate wind-up of the&nbsp;plan.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(5)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Recorded
at cost. This line item also includes accrued interest. </FONT></DD></DL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Both
the Company's cash equivalents and short-term investments are classified within Level&nbsp;2 of the fair value hierarchy because they are held to maturity and are valued using
interest rates observable at commonly quoted intervals. Cash equivalents are market securities with remaining maturities of three months or less at the date of&nbsp;purchase. The short-term
investments are market securities with remaining maturities of over three&nbsp;months at the date of&nbsp;purchase. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company's available-for-sale equity securities valued using quoted market prices in active markets are classified as Level&nbsp;1 of the fair value hierarchy. The fair
value of these securities are calculated as the quoted market price of the security multiplied by the quantity of shares held by the Company. The Company's available-for-sale
securities classified as Level&nbsp;2 of the fair value hierarchy consist of equity warrants. The fair value of these Level&nbsp;2 securities are calculated based on the broker-dealer quotation
multiplied by the quantity of equity warrants held by the Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
the event that a decline in the fair value of an investment occurs and the decline in value is considered to be other-than-temporary, an impairment charge is recorded in the
consolidated statement of income and a new cost basis for the investment is established. The Company assesses whether a decline in value is considered to be
other-than-temporary by considering available evidence, including changes in general market conditions, specific industry and individual company data, the length of time and
the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial condition and the near-term prospects of the individual investment. New evidence could become available in future
periods which would affect this assessment and thus could result in material impairment charges with respect to those investments for which the cost basis exceeds its fair&nbsp;value. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SHAREHOLDERS' EQUITY  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>During
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company implemented a restricted share unit plan for certain employees. A deferred compensation balance was recorded for the total
grant-date value on the date of the grant. The deferred compensation balance </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SHAREHOLDERS' EQUITY (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>was
recorded as a reduction of shareholders' equity and is being amortized as compensation expense (or&nbsp;capitalized to construction in progress) over the applicable vesting&nbsp;period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>During
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company transferred $4.0&nbsp;million (2009&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$3.0&nbsp;million) to an employee benefit trust
(the&nbsp;"Trust") that then purchased shares of the Company in the open market. For accounting purposes, the Trust is treated as a variable interest entity and consolidated in the accounts of the
Company. On consolidation, the dividends paid on the shares held by the Trust were eliminated. The shares purchased and held by the Trust are treated as not being outstanding for the basic earnings
per share ("EPS") calculations. They are amortized back into basic EPS over the vesting period. All of the shares held by the Trust were included in the diluted EPS calculations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>For
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, the Company's warrants were dilutive and were included in the calculation of diluted net income per share. </FONT></P>

following table presents the maximum number of common shares that would be outstanding if all instruments outstanding at March&nbsp;31, 2010 were&nbsp;exercised: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AVAILABLE-FOR-SALE SECURITIES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>During
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company received proceeds of $0.5&nbsp;million (2009&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$0.5&nbsp;million) from the sale of certain
available-for-sale securities and recognized a gain before taxes of $0.4&nbsp;million (2009&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$0.2&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
cost of an available-for-sale security was determined based on the average cost. Available-for-sale securities are carried at fair value and
comprise the&nbsp;following: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
Company holds a position in Goldcorp&nbsp;Inc. warrants that were in an unrealized loss position of $3.3&nbsp;million at March&nbsp;31, 2010 (December&nbsp;31,
2009&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$nil). The Company believes the impairment is not other than temporary as the duration of the unrealized loss was less than three months and that
subsequent to the first quarter of 2010 the unrealized loss had fully&nbsp;reversed. The Goldcorp warrants have an exercise price of C$34.76 and expire in June&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LONG-TERM DEBT  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>During
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company drew down an additional $20.0&nbsp;million from the credit facilities
(2009&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$215.0&nbsp;million) and incurred $7.0&nbsp;million of interest costs (2009&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$1.1&nbsp;million), of which
$4.6&nbsp;million was capitalized to property, plant and mine development (2009&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$1.1&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>At
March&nbsp;31, 2010, the credit facilities were drawn down by a total of $735.0&nbsp;million (December&nbsp;31, 2009&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;$715.0&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;INCOME TAXES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>On
December&nbsp;12, 2008, the Company executed a Canadian federal tax election to start using the US dollar as its functional currency for federal Canadian income tax purposes. As the related tax
legislation was enacted in the first quarter of 2009, this election applies to taxation years ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 and subsequent. It was determined upon filing the 2008 income tax return
that this election resulted in a deferred tax benefit of $21.0&nbsp;million for the period ended March&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
tax effect of other comprehensive income ("OCI") for the period is comprised of the following amounts: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 10.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>In
the first quarter of 2010, to mitigate the risks associated with fluctuating zinc prices, the Company entered into a zero-cost collar to hedge the price of zinc associated with the
LaRonde Mine's 2010 production. The purchase of zinc put options has been financed through selling zinc call options at a higher level such that the net premium payable to the counterparty by the
Company is nil. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>A
total of 15,000&nbsp;metric tonnes of zinc call options were written at a strike price of $2,500 per metric tonne with 1,500&nbsp;metric tonnes expiring each month beginning March&nbsp;31,
2010. A total of 15,000&nbsp;metric tonnes of zinc put options were purchased at a strike price of $2,200 per metric tonne with 1,500&nbsp;metric tonnes expiring each month beginning
March&nbsp;31, 2010. While setting a minimum price, the zero-cost collar strategy also limits participation to zinc prices above $2,500 per metric tonne. These contracts did not qualify
for hedge accounting under ASC 815&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Derivatives and Hedging. Gains or losses, along with mark-to-market adjustments are recognized in the
loss on derivative financial instruments component of the consolidated statements of income. The March options expired out of the money and as of March&nbsp;31, 2010, a
mark-to-market loss of $0.5&nbsp;million was&nbsp;recognized. There were no metal derivative positions in the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2009. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
fair values of the Company's current financial assets and liabilities approximate their carrying values as at March&nbsp;31, 2010. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;COMMITMENTS, CONTINGENCIES, AND GUARANTEES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>As
part of its ongoing business and operations, the Company has been required to provide assurance in the form of letters of credit for environmental and site restoration costs, custom credits,
government grants and other general corporate purposes. As at March&nbsp;31, 2010, the total amount of these guarantees was $120.5&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 12.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SEGMENTED INFORMATION  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Agnico-Eagle
predominantly operates in a single industry, namely exploration for and production of gold. Based on the internal reporting structure and the nature of the Company's activities, the
Company identifies its reportable segments as those consolidated mining operations or functional groups that represent more than 10% of the combined revenue, profit or loss or total assets of all
reported operating segments. Consolidated mining operations or functional groups not meeting this threshold are aggregated at the </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=21,EFW="2198467",CP="AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED",DN="2",CHK=961973,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK125:[10ZAZ1.10ZAZ12201]FK12201A.;29',USER='AGAETZ',CD='12-MAY-2010;10:44' -->
<A NAME="page_fk12201_1_21"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
AGNICO-EAGLE MINES LIMITED </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> (thousands of United States dollars except share and per share amounts, unless otherwise indicated)<BR>
(Unaudited)<BR>
March 31, 2010 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 13.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SUBSEQUENT EVENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Subsequent
to the first quarter of 2010, the Company closed a private placement of an aggregate of $600&nbsp;million of guaranteed senior unsecured notes due 2017, 2020 and 2022 (the&nbsp;"Notes")
with a weighted average maturity of 9.84&nbsp;years and weighted average yield of 6.59%. Net proceeds from the offering of the Notes will be used to repay amounts under the Company's credit
facilities. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Also
subsequent to the first quarter of 2010, the Company and Comaplex Minerals Corp. ("Comaplex") jointly announced that they entered into a definitive agreement whereby the Company will acquire all
of the shares of Comaplex that it does not already own. Under the terms of the transaction, each shareholder of Comaplex other than Agnico-Eagle, will receive 0.1576 of an Agnico-Eagle share per
Comaplex share. Additionally, at closing, each Comaplex shareholder other than Agnico-Eagle and Perfora Investments S.a.r.l. ("Perfora") will receive one common share of a newly formed, wholly owned,
subsidiary of Comaplex ("New&nbsp;Comaplex") in respect of each Comaplex&nbsp;share. The Company expects to issue approximately 10.2&nbsp;million shares to the shareholders of Comaplex other
than Agnico-Eagle. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
transaction contemplates that Comaplex will transfer to New&nbsp;Comaplex all assets and related liabilities other than those relating to the Meliadine properties and related assets. These
assets include all of Comaplex's net cash, the non-Meliadine mineral
properties, all oil and gas properties, and investments. The shares of New&nbsp;Comaplex will be distributed to the shareholders of Comaplex, other than Agnico-Eagle and&nbsp;Perfora. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>The
transaction is subject to approval by Comaplex shareholders and court and regulatory approvals, with an expected closing date in July&nbsp;2010. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1><B> 14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;COMPARATIVE FIGURES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Certain
items in the comparative interim consolidated financial statements have been reclassified from statements previously presented to conform to the presentation of the March&nbsp;31, 2010
interim consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>21</FONT></P>

  <us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;3.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;ACCOUNTING POLICIES &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;These interim consolidated financial statements follow the same accounting policies and methods of their application as the December&amp;nbsp;31, 2009 audited annual consolidated financial statements except for the changes discussed below. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Recently Adopted Accounting Pronouncements&lt;/u&gt; &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Variable Interest Entities&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;In June&amp;nbsp;2009, the FASB issued an amendment to its guidance for consolidation accounting to require an entity to perform a qualitative analysis to determine whether the enterprise's variable interest gives it a controlling financial interest in a VIE. The updated guidance also requires ongoing reassessments of the primary beneficiary of a VIE. Based on the Company's assessment, these changes do not have an impact on the accounting for our existing&amp;nbsp;VIE. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Fair Value Accounting&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;In January&amp;nbsp;2010, the FASB guidance for fair value measurements and disclosures was updated to require additional disclosures. The updated guidance was effective for the Company's fiscal year beginning January&amp;nbsp;1, 2010, with the exception of the level&amp;nbsp;3 disaggregation which is effective for the Company's fiscal year beginning January&amp;nbsp;2, 2011. Based on the Company's assessment, these changes do not have an impact on the Company's required disclosures. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
</us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock>
  <aem:BasisOfPresentationTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;1.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;BASIS OF PRESENTATION &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The accompanying unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of Agnico-Eagle Mines Limited ("Agnico-Eagle" or the&amp;nbsp;"Company") have been prepared in accordance with United&amp;nbsp;States generally accepted accounting principles ("GAAP") in US dollars. They do not include all of the disclosures required by GAAP for annual financial statements. Accordingly, these unaudited interim consolidated financial statements should be read in conjunction with the fiscal 2009 annual consolidated financial statements, including the accounting policies and notes thereto, included in the Annual Report and Annual Information Form/Form&amp;nbsp;20-F for the year ended December&amp;nbsp;31, 2009. In the opinion of management, the unaudited interim consolidated financial statements reflect all adjustments, which consist only of normal and recurring adjustments necessary to present fairly the financial position as at March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010 and the results o
f operations and cash flows for the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010 and&amp;nbsp;2009. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Operating results for the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010 are not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for the full year ending December&amp;nbsp;31,&amp;nbsp;2010.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
</aem:BasisOfPresentationTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;11.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;COMMITMENTS, CONTINGENCIES, AND GUARANTEES &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;As part of its ongoing business and operations, the Company has been required to provide assurance in the form of letters of credit for environmental and site restoration costs, custom credits, government grants and other general corporate purposes. As at March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010, the total amount of these guarantees was $120.5&amp;nbsp;million.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
</us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:DerivativeInstrumentsAndHedgingActivitiesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;10.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;In the first quarter of 2010, to mitigate the risks associated with fluctuating zinc prices, the Company entered into a zero-cost collar to hedge the price of zinc associated with the LaRonde Mine's 2010 production. The purchase of zinc put options has been financed through selling zinc call options at a higher level such that the net premium payable to the counterparty by the Company is nil. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;A total of 15,000&amp;nbsp;metric tonnes of zinc call options were written at a strike price of $2,500 per metric tonne with 1,500&amp;nbsp;metric tonnes expiring each month beginning March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010. A total of 15,000&amp;nbsp;metric tonnes of zinc put options were purchased at a strike price of $2,200 per metric tonne with 1,500&amp;nbsp;metric tonnes expiring each month beginning March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010. While setting a minimum price, the zero-cost collar strategy also limits participation to zinc prices above $2,500 per metric tonne. These contracts did not qualify for hedge accounting under ASC 815&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;Derivatives and Hedging. Gains or losses, along with mark-to-market adjustments are recognized in the loss on derivative financial instruments component of the consolidated statements of income. The March options expired out of the money and as of March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010, a mark-to-market loss of $0.5&amp;nbsp;millio
n was&amp;nbsp;recognized. There were no metal derivative positions in the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2009. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The fair values of the Company's current financial assets and liabilities approximate their carrying values as at March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
</us-gaap:DerivativeInstrumentsAndHedgingActivitiesDisclosureTextBlock>
  <aem:IncomeAndMiningTaxDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;9.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;INCOME TAXES &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;On December&amp;nbsp;12, 2008, the Company executed a Canadian federal tax election to start using the US dollar as its functional currency for federal Canadian income tax purposes. As the related tax legislation was enacted in the first quarter of 2009, this election applies to taxation years ended December&amp;nbsp;31, 2008 and subsequent. It was determined upon filing the 2008 income tax return that this election resulted in a deferred tax benefit of $21.0&amp;nbsp;million for the period ended March&amp;nbsp;31,&amp;nbsp;2009.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The tax effect of other comprehensive income ("OCI") for the period is comprised of the following amounts:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;

&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;12.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;SEGMENTED INFORMATION &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Agnico-Eagle predominantly operates in a single industry, namely exploration for and production of gold. Based on the internal reporting structure and the nature of the Company's activities, the Company identifies its reportable segments as those consolidated mining operations or functional groups that represent more than 10% of the combined revenue, profit or loss or total assets of all reported operating segments. Consolidated mining operations or functional groups not meeting this threshold are aggregated at the &lt;!-- SEQ.=5,FOLIO='19',FILE='DISK125:[10ZAZ1.10ZAZ12201]FK12201A.;29',USER='AGAETZ',CD='12-MAY-2010;10:46' --&gt;applicable geographic region for segment reporting purposes. This structure reflects how the Company manages its business and how it classifies its operations for planning and measuring performance: &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;
&lt;!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE --&gt;
&lt;div align="center"&gt;
&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tr style="HEIGHT: 0px"&gt;&lt;!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS SET --&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times" width="16"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times" align="left" width="64"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times" width="12"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times" align="left" width="390"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS END --&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr style="HEIGHT: 0px" valign="top"&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Canada:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;LaRonde Mine, Lapa Mine, Goldex Mine, Meadowbank Mine, and the Regional Office&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr style="HEIGHT: 0px" valign="top"&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;tr style="HEIGHT: 0px" valign="top"&gt;

&lt;!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE --&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Specific Corporate Head Office income and expense items are noted separately below. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;On May&amp;nbsp;1, 2009, both the Lapa mine and Kittila mine achieved commercial production. The Pinos Altos Mine achieved commercial production on November&amp;nbsp;1, 2009. The Meadowbank Mine achieved commercial production March&amp;nbsp;1, 2010. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;

</us-gaap:SegmentReportingDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:ScheduleOfSubsequentEventsTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;13.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;SUBSEQUENT EVENTS &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Subsequent to the first quarter of 2010, the Company closed a private placement of an aggregate of $600&amp;nbsp;million of guaranteed senior unsecured notes due 2017, 2020 and 2022 (the&amp;nbsp;"Notes") with a weighted average maturity of 9.84&amp;nbsp;years and weighted average yield of 6.59%. Net proceeds from the offering of the Notes will be used to repay amounts under the Company's credit facilities. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Also subsequent to the first quarter of 2010, the Company and Comaplex Minerals Corp. ("Comaplex") jointly announced that they entered into a definitive agreement whereby the Company will acquire all of the shares of Comaplex that it does not already own. Under the terms of the transaction, each shareholder of Comaplex other than Agnico-Eagle, will receive 0.1576 of an Agnico-Eagle share per Comaplex share. Additionally, at closing, each Comaplex shareholder other than Agnico-Eagle and Perfora Investments S.a.r.l. ("Perfora") will receive one common share of a newly formed, wholly owned, subsidiary of Comaplex ("New&amp;nbsp;Comaplex") in respect of each Comaplex&amp;nbsp;share. The Company expects to issue approximately 10.2&amp;nbsp;million shares to the shareholders of Comaplex other than Agnico-Eagle. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The transaction contemplates that Comaplex will transfer to New&amp;nbsp;Comaplex all assets and related liabilities other than those relating to the Meliadine properties and related assets. These assets include all of Comaplex's net cash, the non-Meliadine mineral properties, all oil and gas properties, and investments. The shares of New&amp;nbsp;Comaplex will be distributed to the shareholders of Comaplex, other than Agnico-Eagle and&amp;nbsp;Perfora. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The transaction is subject to approval by Comaplex shareholders and court and regulatory approvals, with an expected closing date in July&amp;nbsp;2010. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
</us-gaap:ScheduleOfSubsequentEventsTextBlock>
  <aem:UseOfEstimatesTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;2.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;USE OF ESTIMATES &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The preparation of the financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes. Management believes that the estimates used in the preparation of the interim consolidated financial statements are reasonable and prudent; however, actual results could differ from these estimates. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
</aem:UseOfEstimatesTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:StockholdersEquityNoteDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;5.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;SHAREHOLDERS' EQUITY &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;During the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2009, the Company implemented a restricted share unit plan for certain employees. A deferred compensation balance was recorded for the total grant-date value on the date of the grant. The deferred compensation balance &lt;!-- SEQ.=2,FOLIO='16',FILE='DISK125:[10ZAZ1.10ZAZ12201]FK12201A.;29',USER='AGAETZ',CD='12-MAY-2010;10:46' --&gt;was recorded as a reduction of shareholders' equity and is being amortized as compensation expense (or&amp;nbsp;capitalized to construction in progress) over the applicable vesting&amp;nbsp;period. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;During the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010, the Company transferred $4.0&amp;nbsp;million (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$3.0&amp;nbsp;million) to an employee benefit trust (the&amp;nbsp;"Trust") that then purchased shares of the Company in the open market. For accounting purposes, the Trust is treated as a variable interest entity and consolidated in the accounts of the Company. On consolidation, the dividends paid on the shares held by the Trust were eliminated. The shares purchased and held by the Trust are treated as not being outstanding for the basic earnings per share ("EPS") calculations. They are amortized back into basic EPS over the vesting period. All of the shares held by the Trust were included in the diluted EPS calculations. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;For the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, the Company's warrants were dilutive and were included in the calculation of diluted net income per share. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The following table presents the maximum number of common shares that would be outstanding if all instruments outstanding at March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010 were&amp;nbsp;exercised: &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;

&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1pt solid; FONT-FAMILY: times" align="right" colspan="2"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times" align="right"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;173,799,185&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 2.25pt double; FONT-FAMILY: times" align="right" colspan="2"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE --&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;During the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010, 2,755,080 (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;2,251,000) options were granted with an exercise price of C$56.95 (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;C$62.77), 59,325 (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;602,300) employee stock options were exercised for cash of $1.3&amp;nbsp;million (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$15.0&amp;nbsp;million), and 10,550 (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;70,000) options were cancelled with a weighted average exercise price of C$49.88 (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;C$56.50). &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  <us-gaap:AvailableForSaleSecuritiesTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;7.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;AVAILABLE-FOR-SALE SECURITIES&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;During the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010, the Company received proceeds of $0.5&amp;nbsp;million (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$0.5&amp;nbsp;million) from the sale of certain available-for-sale securities and recognized a gain before taxes of $0.4&amp;nbsp;million (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$0.2&amp;nbsp;million). &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The cost of an available-for-sale security was determined based on the average cost. Available-for-sale securities are carried at fair value and comprise the&amp;nbsp;following: &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;
&lt;!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE --&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The Company holds a position in Goldcorp&amp;nbsp;Inc. warrants that were in an unrealized loss position of $3.3&amp;nbsp;million at March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010 (December&amp;nbsp;31, 2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$nil). The Company believes the impairment is not other than temporary as the duration of the unrealized loss was less than three months and that subsequent to the first quarter of 2010 the unrealized loss had fully&amp;nbsp;reversed. The Goldcorp warrants have an exercise price of C$34.76 and expire in June&amp;nbsp;2011. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;

  <us-gaap:ScheduleOfLineOfCreditFacilitiesTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;8.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;LONG-TERM DEBT &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;During the three months ended March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010, the Company drew down an additional $20.0&amp;nbsp;million from the credit facilities (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$215.0&amp;nbsp;million) and incurred $7.0&amp;nbsp;million of interest costs (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$1.1&amp;nbsp;million), of which $4.6&amp;nbsp;million was capitalized to property, plant and mine development (2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$1.1&amp;nbsp;million). &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;At March&amp;nbsp;31, 2010, the credit facilities were drawn down by a total of $735.0&amp;nbsp;million (December&amp;nbsp;31, 2009&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;$715.0&amp;nbsp;million). &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
</us-gaap:ScheduleOfLineOfCreditFacilitiesTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:FairValueDisclosuresTextBlock contextRef="D2010Q1">&lt;table style="font-size:10pt; font-family:'Times New Roman',times,serif;"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;4.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENT &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 820&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;Fair Value Measurement and Disclosure (Prior authoritative literature: FASB Statement No.&amp;nbsp;157, "Fair Value Measurements") defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value under GAAP, and requires expanded disclosures about fair value measurements. The three levels of the fair value hierarchy under the Fair Value Measurements and Disclosure Topic of the FASB Accounting Standards Codification&amp;nbsp;are: &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Level&amp;nbsp;1&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;Unadjusted quoted prices in active markets that are accessible at the measurement date for identical, unrestricted assets or&amp;nbsp;liabilities; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Level&amp;nbsp;2&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;Quoted prices in markets that are not active, or inputs that are observable, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of the asset or&amp;nbsp;liability; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Level&amp;nbsp;3&amp;nbsp;&amp;#151;&amp;nbsp;Prices or&amp;nbsp;valuation techniques that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and unobservable (supported by little or no market activity). &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&lt;!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='DISK125:[10ZAZ1.10ZAZ12201]FK12201A.;29',USER='AGAETZ',CD='12-MAY-2010;10:46' --&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Fair value is the value at which a financial instrument could be closed out or sold in a transaction with a willing and knowledgeable counterparty over a period of time consistent with the Company's investment strategy. Fair value is based on quoted market prices, where available. If market quotes are not available, fair value is based on internally developed models that use market-based or independent information as inputs. These models could produce a fair value that may not be reflective of future fair&amp;nbsp;value. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The following table sets forth the Company's financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value within the fair value hierarchy. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;
&lt;!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE --&gt;
&lt;div align="center"&gt;

&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 2.25pt double; FONT-FAMILY: times" align="right" colspan="2"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 2.25pt double; FONT-FAMILY: times" align="right" colspan="2"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 2.25pt double; FONT-FAMILY: times" align="right" colspan="2"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 2.25pt double; FONT-FAMILY: times" align="right" colspan="2"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE --&gt;&lt;!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="LEFT" --&gt;
&lt;hr style="COLOR: #000000" align="left" width="12%" noshade="noshade" size="1" /&gt;
&lt;dl compact="compact"&gt;
&lt;dt style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: -9pt; FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;(1)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dt&gt;
&lt;dd style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Fair value approximates the carrying amounts due to the short-term nature. &lt;br /&gt;
&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dd&gt;
&lt;dt style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: -9pt; FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;(2)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dt&gt;
&lt;dd style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Recorded at fair value using quoted market prices. &lt;br /&gt;
&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dd&gt;
&lt;dt style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: -9pt; FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;(3)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dt&gt;
&lt;dd style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Recorded at fair value based on broker-dealer quotations. &lt;br /&gt;
&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dd&gt;
&lt;dt style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: -9pt; FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;(4)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dt&gt;
&lt;dd style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Assets for the defined benefit pension plan consists of deposits on hand with regulatory authorities which are refundable when benefit payments are made on the ultimate wind-up of the&amp;nbsp;plan. &lt;br /&gt;
&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dd&gt;
&lt;dt style="MARGIN-BOTTOM: -9pt; FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;(5)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dt&gt;
&lt;dd style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Recorded at cost. This line item also includes accrued interest. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/dd&gt;&lt;/dl&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
&lt;li style="list-style: none"&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;Both the Company's cash equivalents and short-term investments are classified within Level&amp;nbsp;2 of the fair value hierarchy because they are held to maturity and are valued using interest rates observable at commonly quoted intervals. Cash equivalents are market securities with remaining maturities of three months or less at the date of&amp;nbsp;purchase. The short-term investments are market securities with remaining maturities of over three&amp;nbsp;months at the date of&amp;nbsp;purchase. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;The Company's available-for-sale equity securities valued using quoted market prices in active markets are classified as Level&amp;nbsp;1 of the fair value hierarchy. The fair value of these securities are calculated as the quoted market price of the security multiplied by the quantity of shares held by the Company. The Company's available-for-sale securities classified as Level&amp;nbsp;2 of the fair value hierarchy consist of equity warrants. The fair value of these Level&amp;nbsp;2 securities are calculated based on the broker-dealer quotation multiplied by the quantity of equity warrants held by the Company. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="FONT-FAMILY: times"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;In the event that a decline in the fair value of an investment occurs and the decline in value is considered to be other-than-temporary, an impairment charge is recorded in the consolidated statement of income and a new cost basis for the investment is established. The Company assesses whether a decline in value is considered to be other-than-temporary by considering available evidence, including changes in general market conditions, specific industry and individual company data, the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has been less than cost, the financial condition and the near-term prospects of the individual investment. New evidence could become available in future periods which would affect this assessment and thus could result in material impairment charges with respect to those investments for which the cost basis exceeds its fair&amp;nbsp;value. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
</us-gaap:FairValueDisclosuresTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:DefinedBenefitPlanAmountsRecognizedInOtherComprehensiveIncomeNetGainLossBeforeTax contextRef="D2009Q1" decimals="-3" unitRef="USD">-7000</us-gaap:DefinedBenefitPlanAmountsRecognizedInOtherComprehensiveIncomeNetGainLossBeforeTax>
  <us-gaap:DefinedBenefitPlanAmountsRecognizedInOtherComprehensiveIncomeNetGainLossBeforeTax contextRef="D2010Q1" decimals="0" unitRef="USD">47000</us-gaap:DefinedBenefitPlanAmountsRecognizedInOtherComprehensiveIncomeNetGainLossBeforeTax>
